üìú The Complete Game

1. e4 c6 - The Caro-Kann Defense begins

11. Bf4 b5 - Desperate counterplay

17. Bf5 exf5 - Forced trade
18. Rxe7 Bxe7 - Rook penetration

üîç Critical Analysis

The Fatal Move: 7...h6

Kasparov played this move thinking Deep Blue wouldn't sacrifice on e6. He was wrong.

The Crushing Response: 8.Nxe6!

Deep Blue's knight sacrifice destroyed Black's king safety permanently.

Opening Book vs. Human Psychology:

Deep Blue had this line in its opening book, while Kasparov expected it to calculate and reject the sacrifice.

The Resignation:

After 19.c4, Kasparov's position was hopeless. The knight on d5 is trapped and lost.

‚ö° The Critical Moment: Move 8

When Deep Blue played 8.Nxe6!, it wasn't just capturing a pawn‚Äîit was capturing the future. This knight sacrifice, programmed into the opening book just that morning, would echo through the decades as the moment artificial intelligence announced itself to the world.

Kasparov later said he expected the computer to be "materialistic" and refuse the sacrifice. Instead, Deep Blue played like Tal, like Nezhmetdinov, like the greatest attacking players in history‚Äîbut with silicon precision.

And that's when Garry Kasparov realized something that would haunt him for years to come: the machine hadn't just beaten him‚Äîit had beaten him beautifully. With style. With flair. With the kind of intuitive genius that was supposed to be uniquely human. In that moment, watching his king flee across the board like a refugee, Kasparov understood that the future had arrived, and it played better chess than he did.
